713059f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, north side, between Broadway (right) and Seventh Ave. (left), showing a triangular excavation extending to 43rd Street, that is today (1937) occupied by the Times Building. This clearance was created by the demolition of 6, 4-story houses, which bore Nos. 1469 to 1485 Broadway and 603 to 619 Seventh Ave. This area is now known as
Times Square.
December 4, 1901.
NEG #3510

717475f.text:
Broadway, west side, from 42nd to 45th Streets. At the left, construction work on the New York Times Building is under way. At 43rd Street is the Hotel Cadillac, and above it is Rector's which, along with the corner building at 44th Street, will soon be replaced by the Hotel Claridge. From 44th to 45th Streets are the Criterion and New York theatres. The building which they occu,y, which at the time of this picture is called the Crystal Gardens, will be demolished in 1935. Broadway is badly torn up from subway construction, which is nearly completed.
1903.
Brown Brothers.
NEG #4463

713054f-a.text:
42nd Street at the S.E. corner of Broadway.
About 1915.

717476f-a.text:
Broadway at the S.E. corner of 42nd Street. What would have been a good northward view of Broadway is blocked by the subway kiosk.
About 1921.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

713060f-a.text:
West 42nd street, north side, west from and including Broadway, to and including Seventh Ave. Prominent building shown is the Times
Building. A general view north is also shown.
About 1924.
Ewing Galloway.  neg #626

713061f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, west from Broadway, showing the Times
Building in the foreground.
1926.
Brown Brothers.

717484f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from 42nd Street. In the foreground are the Longacre and Fitzgerald Buildings, and the entrance to the George M. Cohan Theatre. In the next block are the Hotels Cadillac and Claridge, and above them the Criterion and New York theatres.
At the extreme left is the Hotel Astor.
1926.
Brown Brothers.
., ~260E

723532f-a.text:
The New York Times Building, Broadway, west side, from 42nd to 43rd Streets. At the right is the Paramount Building and Theatre.
About 1927.
Ewing Galloway.

713062f-a.text:
Steuben Tavern, 42nd Street, south side, from Broadway to Seventh Avenue. This is a very new restaurant, as shown; it was established here shortly after the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The Lexington Avenue Steuben Tavern is older.
1934.
Martin Haggett, Photographer.
Gift of New York Times.
NEG #3247

713051f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, south side, west from (No. 138; the Cameo Theatre) a point slightly east of Broadway and across same. The 15-story structure on the left is the former Knickerbocker Hotel that has been converted to business purposes. It bears Nos. 1462-1470 Broadway and stands at the S.E. corner of West 42nd Street. West of same appears a low structure occupying the apex of a triangular plot between Broadway and Seventh Ave. Progressing in the same direction one sees the 24-story Candler Building and the modern Graybar Building; the latter being between Eighth and Ninth Aves. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

713051f-b.text:
West 42nd Street, south side, west from (No. 138; the Cameo Theatre) a point slightly east of Broadway and across same. The 15-story structure on the left is the former Knickerbocker Hotel that has been converted to business purposes. It bears Nos. 1462-1470 Broadway and stands at the S.E. corner of West 42nd Street. West of same appears a low structure occupying the apex of a triangular plot between Broadway and Seventh Ave. Progressing in the same direction one sees the 24-story Candler Building and the modern Graybar Building; the latter being between Eighth and Ninth Aves. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

717485f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from but not including West 42nd
Street.
September 26, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

723544f-c.text:
Times Square, north from West 42nd Street (foreground) and showing mainly structures lining the east side of this intersecting point of Broadway and Seventh Ave. This is a set of 3 views, No. 2 of which is from West 43rd Street. No. 3 shows the new building on the east side of same, between 44th and 45th Streets that houses the Criterion Theatre and the International Casino. Atop same is the huge electric display sign of Wrigleys. For earlier views of this area, see the Broadway files.
September 14, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723544f-a.text:
Times Square, north from West 42nd Street (foreground) and showing mainly structures lining the east side of this intersecting point of Broadway and Seventh Ave. This is a set of 3 views, No. 2 of which is from West 43rd Street. No. 3 shows the new building on the east side of same, between 44th and 45th Streets that houses the Criterion Theatre and the International Casino. Atop same is the huge electric display sign of Wrigleys. For earlier views of this area, see the Broadway files.

717473f-b.text:
(1) Broadway, west side and 42nd Street looking southwards, showing the Brokaw Brothers Building on right.
(2) Broadway and 42nd Street, showing W.P.A. reconstruction
work.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: September 1933
NO REPROODUCTIrNS  View 2: June 2, 1937

717481f-c.text:
(1) and (2
1490-1486 ind 1480-76 Broadway, east side, south from West 43rd (left) to and including 42nd (right) Streets, showing two Times Square buildings. The George M. Cohan Theatre, a structure around the corner has its main entrance at the southern extremity of the Fitz-Gerald Building; No. 1490-86.
This set of 2 views consists of a negative and a positive.
1936.
2~ 2:9
W.P.A. Photo.
(3)
A southwestward view over the cleared site of the Fitz-Gerald Building from W. 43rd Street and east of Broadway. At the right appears
a portion of the Times Building.
March 27, 1939.
R. W. BI1

713053f-a.text: 140 West 42nd Street adjoining the S.E. corner of Broadway. Shown is the street level only of the Coral Gables Building that was devoted to sales of “Floridian” property of that name near Miami. About 1926

713058f-a.text:
140 W. 42nd Street, north side, from Broadway (right) to Seventh Avenue (loft) showing the triangular site of the present Times Building. The ornate building shown is inscribed "Charles Thorley, A. D. 1896." At the loft is Oscar Hammersteins "Victoria".
May 11, 1900
Gift of Urbrock Collection
H. N. Tiomann, photo

732258f-a.title: Newspapers - The New York Times - Buildings.
732258f-a.text:
"The New York Times", moved uptown to 42nd Street, in 1905, at the southern junction of Broadway and Seventh Ave.,(comnonly known as Times Square). It was housed in this building up to 1913, when an annex was required.
Gift of "The New York Times".

717496f-c.text:
Broadway, at W. 44th Street as viewed northwestward from the Bush Terminal Building on 42nd Street. This location appears in the center of the view and shows at the S.W., the N.A. and the S.E. corners respectively, the Paramount Building, the Hotel Astor and the Hotel Claridge. In the foreground appears W. 43rd Street with the 12 story Cadillac Hotel to the east of Times Square. Adjacent to same and only 6 stories in height is the Hotel Yates.
March 18, 1929.
P.L. Sperr
Astor Hotel in daytime. 1926
Astor Hotel at Midnight
